channel.title: Skilled RSC - New Server, New Design
channel.description:
[b]Skilled RSC[/b] [b]Non - VPS for now but still 20/7[/b], The 4 hours for crashes and downtime! This is our beta test! The moderators and administrators are mature and handle situations very fast and quality alike.
[b]NEW EXP RATES[/b] x30 EXP Regular Players x60 For Premium Members
[u][b]Bug Fixes:[/b][/u]
[ul][li]Fixed The Space in name glitch.[/li] [li]New client sprites![/li] [li]New home[/li][/ul]
[b][i]Client Download:[/i][/b] [b][i]Client Download:[/i][/b] Mediafire: [url=http://www.mediafire.com/download.php?nny5ljnknnn]http://www.mediafire.com/download.php?nny5ljnknnn[/url] MegaUpload: [url=http://www.megaupload.com/?d=SWFISHMS]http://www.megaupload.com/?d=SWFISHMS[/url] [b][i]Staff:[/i][/b] [u]Skilled - Owner[/u] There is no mods and no admins, apply today. [u][i][b]Pictures[/b][/i][/u] [i]Client[/i] [img]http://img385.imageshack.us/img385/6350/client.png[/img] [i][b]Webiste in signature![/b][/i]
~Skilled

item.title: Skilled RSC - New Server, New Design
item.dc:creator: @KO9 KO9
item.description:
@KO9 wrote:

[quote=“Kozy, post:10, topic:282036”][quote author=liquidazer link=topic=372678.msg2812921#msg2812921 date=1244098807]
people on this forum talk about DDOS as if they know what it means or does. Seriously, a DDOS cannot break or malfunction any of your computer equipment. Unless you added your own computer to a existing botnet, most attacks are futile. For example, my friend is hosting a WoW server from his own computer. Americans play this server when it is located in australia. (No lag for americans). Someone attempted to DDOS his server + website. just to proove how pathetic this attack was against his server: His overall CPU increased by 10% and stayed that way, he then unloaded all of it a redirected it back to the proxy it was being sent from using a “little program”. The americans or australians didnt even notice it. It can only cut out your internet connection if your ISP is retarded.
[/quote]

Nobody ever said it will break your computer. It will hit you offline for quite a bit of time, in which you have to reset your router and such, which is extremely boring. Oh, and the attack your friend got was jack shit. A recent attack upon RscR’s Dedicated server, brought down 100+ of the Dedicated server’s customers, due to them being on the same line. That is a real DDoS attack, as it involved tons of Bots, and was most likely a rented botnet.

Cut out your internet if your isp is retarded? LMAO. Thats why $500 a month dedi’s go down whenever DDoS’ed by most 1k+ nets? Yeah Man, you know what your talking about totally -.- If it was the “ISP” that determined if you hot hit ofline, I think ppl wouldn’t spend $100’s monthly for software/hardware firewalls, and just switch ISPs.

-Kozy[/quote]

Rofl, you’re paying $500 for a dedi which is using a shared line across 100 servers? Get your money back…

Read full topic
item.source: Skilled RSC - New Server, New Design

item.title: Skilled RSC - New Server, New Design
item.dc:creator: @the_man880 the man880
item.description:
@the_man880 wrote:

[quote=“Kozy, post:13, topic:282036”][quote author=liquidazer link=topic=372678.msg2813042#msg2813042 date=1244116014]
Actually if your ISP isnt retarded which I bet most american ones are. Australian ones provide multiple fibre-cable backbone connections to seperate servers providing the same service to provide excellent performance. ( From ISP website ): “We also use load balancing technology to distribute web traffic between multiple servers, further increasing availability, performance and security.”, "We use only the latest, cutting edge hardware and software to give you superior performance with minimal downtime. Reliable network features Dell PowerEdge high speed servers, Cisco network hardware, and multiple fibre optic connections to the Internet backbone. "

Its exactly why companies like blizzard and jagex do it to prevent no lives like yourself from getting their way on the games. I’m sure you know what your talking about as well, indeed.

Also, people like “tewl” claim that they own botnets when they add their own computers to one that is networked publicly. The sad thing is that these people have no idea how to hack and claim themselves to be gods. These public botnets can also be quite strong if known how to use them, and no offence. But why do you put “- Kozy” at the end of everything you post?

P.S: Im not having a go at you mate.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: June 04, 2009, 05:57:05 am[/size][hr][quote author=Kozy link=topic=372678.msg2812556#msg2812556 date=1244073897]
Just because your using No-ip doesn’t mean a DDoS Atk wont fuck up your computer.

-Kozy
[/quote]

You were saying?
[/quote]

I put “-Kozy” at the end of my posts, because I use/still to be part of gaming community forums, where there were no “logins”.

-Kozy[/quote][quote=“Kozy, post:13, topic:282036”][quote author=liquidazer link=topic=372678.msg2813042#msg2813042 date=1244116014]
Actually if your ISP isnt retarded which I bet most american ones are. Australian ones provide multiple fibre-cable backbone connections to seperate servers providing the same service to provide excellent performance. ( From ISP website ): “We also use load balancing technology to distribute web traffic between multiple servers, further increasing availability, performance and security.”, "We use only the latest, cutting edge hardware and software to give you superior performance with minimal downtime. Reliable network features Dell PowerEdge high speed servers, Cisco network hardware, and multiple fibre optic connections to the Internet backbone. "

Its exactly why companies like blizzard and jagex do it to prevent no lives like yourself from getting their way on the games. I’m sure you know what your talking about as well, indeed.

Also, people like “tewl” claim that they own botnets when they add their own computers to one that is networked publicly. The sad thing is that these people have no idea how to hack and claim themselves to be gods. These public botnets can also be quite strong if known how to use them, and no offence. But why do you put “- Kozy” at the end of everything you post?

P.S: Im not having a go at you mate.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: June 04, 2009, 05:57:05 am[/size][hr][quote author=Kozy link=topic=372678.msg2812556#msg2812556 date=1244073897]
Just because your using No-ip doesn’t mean a DDoS Atk wont fuck up your computer.

-Kozy
[/quote]

You were saying?
[/quote]

I put “-Kozy” at the end of my posts, because I use/still to be part of gaming community forums, where there were no “logins”.

-Kozy[/quote]

It’s kinda funny actually it works like this,

i’m gay

-Jake

item.title: Skilled RSC - New Server, New Design
item.dc:creator: @Kozy Kozy
item.description:
@Kozy wrote:

[quote=“froggie, post:15, topic:282036”]I can vouch for the mention of a DDoS attack knocking a home computer offline.

I sit behind two routers, one is a Belkin Wireless G router which is connected to the cable modem, and the other is an Apple Airport Express 802.11N router. The G offers ethernet and 802.11B/G compatible wifi to my legacy hardware and the Airport Express gives me Wireless N at 270 mbps for my newer computers.

DARScape has been under a constant UDP/TCP SYN flood for weeks. Our dedi host, Sharktech.net does a great job at filtering the flooding and the intrusion detection firewall does the rest.

I briefly moved the dynamic IP domain from the IP belonging to my dedi to my residential IP address. (Use of a No-IP.org) My Belkin router has a built in hardware firewall which had been set to enabled. I had set port forwarding and was running a replica website/game server as a test environment. The Airport router froze, then the Belkin froze. Ability to connect to the internet stopped. I rebooted the routers and my cable modem only to find it happen again. Roadrunner ISP didn’t seem to be filtering anything, the whole flood was coming through and exceeding my 512mbps upstream bandwidth allowance.

I was lucky to have a Smartphone with an internet connection so that I could go to DynDNS.org and disable the IP forwarding and redirect it back to the dedi.[/quote]

Ty, now maybe people will believe me 0,-.

-Kozy

Read full topic
item.source: Skilled RSC - New Server, New Design

item.title: Skilled RSC - New Server, New Design
item.dc:creator: @froggie froggie
item.description:
@froggie wrote:

I can vouch for the mention of a DDoS attack knocking a home computer offline.

I sit behind two routers, one is a Belkin Wireless G router which is connected to the cable modem, and the other is an Apple Airport Express 802.11N router. The G offers ethernet and 802.11B/G compatible wifi to my legacy hardware and the Airport Express gives me Wireless N at 270 mbps for my newer computers.

DARScape has been under a constant UDP/TCP SYN flood for weeks. Our dedi host, Sharktech.net does a great job at filtering the flooding and the intrusion detection firewall does the rest.

I briefly moved the dynamic IP domain from the IP belonging to my dedi to my residential IP address. (Use of a No-IP.org) My Belkin router has a built in hardware firewall which had been set to enabled. I had set port forwarding and was running a replica website/game server as a test environment. The Airport router froze, then the Belkin froze. Ability to connect to the internet stopped. I rebooted the routers and my cable modem only to find it happen again. Roadrunner ISP didn’t seem to be filtering anything, the whole flood was coming through and exceeding my 512mbps upstream bandwidth allowance.

I was lucky to have a Smartphone with an internet connection so that I could go to DynDNS.org and disable the IP forwarding and redirect it back to the dedi.

Read full topic

P.S: Im not having a go at you mate.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: June 04, 2009, 05:57:05 am[/size][hr][quote author=Kozy link=topic=372678.msg2812556#msg2812556 date=1244073897]

liquidazer:

people on this forum talk about DDOS as if they know what it means or does. Seriously, a DDOS cannot break or malfunction any of your computer equipment. Unless you added your own computer to a existing botnet, most attacks are futile. For example, my friend is hosting a WoW server from his own computer. Someone attempted to DDOS his server + website. just to proove how pathetic this attack was against his server: His overall CPU increased by 10% and stayed that way, he then unloaded all of it a redirected it back to the proxy it was being sent from using a “little program”. The americans or australians didnt even notice it. It can only cut out your internet connection if your ISP is retarded.

Nobody ever said it will break your computer. It will hit you offline for quite a bit of time, in which you have to reset your router and such, which is extremely boring.
